metadata.dc:author: Gómez-Dantés, Octavio
metadata.dc:description: Cesarean sections rates have increased considerably in high- and middle-income countries in recent years. In Latin America the rates of surgical births reached 30% in Brazil, 40% in Chile, and 36% in Mexico. This essay describes the relationship of cesarean section with several mythological characters, presents a brief history of surgical births, and discusses the possible origin of its explosive increase. Among the factors associated to this epidemic we can mention economic incentives, a mounting supply of specialists, and the lack of comprehensive information on birth alternatives for pregnant women. The essay concludes with a call for a generalized control of this procedure based on evidence gathered through different kinds of interventions.
metadata.dc:title: El secuestro de Lucina (o cómo detener la epidemia de cesáreas).
[Lucina's kidnap (or how to stop the cesarean section epidemic)].
